command.headquarters_location: El Alamein sector, Egypt - XIII Corps southern sector with 7th Armoured Division and 50th Infantry Division

Ordnance QF 25-pounder Gun-Howitzer.note: Three field regiments (24 guns each) - standard British infantry division artillery establishment

Ordnance QF 6-pounder (57mm).note: Modern anti-tank gun, division re-equipped with 6-pdrs before deployment to North Africa

Ordnance QF 2-pounder.note: Remaining 2-pounders retained for local defense roles

supply_logistics.supply_status: GOOD - Fresh division with full equipment allocation upon arrival in North Africa. Integrated into 8th Army supply system. Static defensive position in XIII Corps southern sector allows stockpiling of supplies. Supply lines run from Alexandria via coastal road to forward dumps.

weather_environment.season_quarter: 1942-Q4 (October-December) - Autumn/Early Winter at El Alamein sector
weather_environment.terrain_type: Western Desert - Southern El Alamein sector (XIII Corps). Mix of sand, rock, and camel scrub. More difficult terrain than northern sector. Static defensive positions along minefields.

subordinate_units.note: Battalions: 1/5th, 1/6th, 1/7th Queen's Royal Regiment (West Surrey). Participated in Operation Braganza 29-30 September 1942 (night raid before El Alamein main battle).

Battalions: 1/7th Queen's Royal Regiment, 4th and 5th Queen's Own Royal West Kent Regiment. Temporarily detached to 2nd New Zealand Division during Alam el Halfa, suffered 697 casualties 3-4 September 1942.
Battalions: 2nd, 4th, and 5th (Cinque Ports) Royal Sussex Regiment

tactical_doctrine.role: Infantry division in XIII Corps southern sector at Second Battle of El Alamein (23 Oct - 11 Nov 1942). Mission: Support 7th Armoured Division operations, hold defensive positions in southern sector, prevent Axis breakthrough, man prepared anti-tank defenses backed by divisional artillery.
special_capabilities: Fresh division with full strength and modern equipment (deployed May 1942)
Territorial Army units with strong regional cohesion (Home Counties - Sussex, Kent, Surrey)
Well-trained in UK before North Africa deployment
Modern 6-pounder anti-tank guns in good supply (by Oct 1942 most British divisions had 6-pdrs)
Prepared defensive positions with dug-in anti-tank guns and artillery support
tactical_innovations: Operation Braganza (29-30 September 1942) - night raid by 131st Brigade before main battle, demonstrating offensive capability
Adaptation to desert warfare during 4-5 month acclimatization period (June-October 1942)
Integration with veteran 7th Armoured Division and 50th Infantry Division in XIII Corps
Effective use of prepared defensive positions with anti-tank guns at Alam el Halfa - inflicted heavy losses on 15th and 21st Panzer Divisions
known_issues: No organic armor (infantry division - depends on attached armor from X Corps or XIII Corps armor assets)
First major action in North Africa - limited desert warfare experience compared to veteran divisions
Arrived mid-1942 - only 4-5 months acclimatization before El Alamein (deployed 29 May 1942)
Territorial Army division adjusting to professional regular army standards in combat theater
Climate adjustment challenges (UK temperate climate to North African desert)
tactical_doctrine.desert_adaptations: Division deployed to North Africa 29 May 1942, arrived Cairo 24 July 1942. Underwent desert acclimatization and training June-September 1942 in Egypt. First combat action: Operation Braganza (29-30 Sep 1942) night raid. Battle of Alam el Halfa (31 Aug - 7 Sep 1942) - two brigades deployed along Alam el Halfa Ridge in prepared defensive positions. Second Battle of El Alamein (23 Oct - 11 Nov 1942) - defended southern sector. Still adapting to desert conditions in Q4 1942 but combat-tested by December. Division disbanded 31 January 1943.

scenario_suitability: Second Battle of El Alamein (23 Oct - 11 Nov 1942) - XIII Corps southern sector defensive battle
Battle of Alam el Halfa (31 Aug - 7 Sep 1942) - defensive battle on prepared positions
Operation Braganza (29-30 Sep 1942) - night raid scenario, small-unit action
Fresh Territorial division vs veteran Axis forces scenarios
Defensive infantry operations in prepared positions
wargaming_data.experience_level: Green to Trained (first major battles Aug-Nov 1942, gained experience rapidly)
special_rules: Fresh troops bonus (full strength, good morale, well-equipped)
Regional cohesion bonus (Home Counties Territorial units - Sussex, Kent, Surrey regiments)
Modern equipment (6-pounder AT guns standard by Oct 1942)
Desert inexperience penalty (first 6 months in theater - applies Q2-Q4 1942)
Prepared defensive positions bonus at Alam el Halfa and El Alamein
historical_engagements: Operation Braganza (29-30 September 1942) - night raid by 131st Brigade before El Alamein

Battle of Alam el Halfa (31 Aug - 7 Sep 1942) - two brigades deployed along Alam el Halfa Ridge, inflicted heavy losses on 15th and 21st Panzer Divisions attacking prepared positions with anti-tank guns and artillery
Second Battle of El Alamein (23 Oct - 11 Nov 1942) - XIII Corps southern sector, supported 7th Armoured Division and 50th Division
Pursuit to Tunisia (November-December 1942) - advanced westwards after Axis withdrawal
Division disbanded 31 January 1943 in North Africa

source: London Gazette Issue 38196 (3 February 1948) - Field Marshal Alexander's Official Despatch: 'The African Campaign from El Alamein to Tunis, 10 August 1942 to 13 May 1943' - Official British government military despatch

Playfair, I.S.O. & Molony, C.J.C. et al. (1966) - 'The Mediterranean and Middle East, Volume IV: The Destruction of the Axis Forces in Africa' - History of the Second World War, United Kingdom Military Series, HMSO (His Majesty's Stationery Office) - British Official History
Carver, Field Marshal Lord (2000) [1962] - 'El Alamein' - Wordsworth Editions, ISBN 978-1-84022-220-3 - First-hand account, Carver commanded 7th Motor Brigade at El Alamein

Buffetaut, Yves (2009) - 'Desert Rats: British 8th Army in North Africa 1941-43' - Osprey Publishing, Battle Orders 028, ISBN 978-1-84603-305-5 - Pages 76-81 document 44th Division deployment at Alam el Halfa: 'two newly arrived brigades of 44th Division along its [Alam el Halfa Ridge] length, backed by its artillery and anti-tank guns'
TM 30-410 Handbook on the British Army (1942) - US War Department Technical Manual - Official Allied reference on British Army organization and equipment
Nafziger Collection: 942bkaa.pdf - Distribution of British Divisions Mid-November 1942 - George Nafziger Order of Battle collection

personnel_and_equipment.estimate_method: Standard British infantry division establishment 1942: ~17,500 personnel (3 infantry brigades of ~5,800 each + divisional troops ~1,100), 72x 25-pdrs (3 field regiments), 48x AT guns (mix of 2-pdr and 6-pdr by Oct 1942), ~3,300 vehicles (trucks, cars, carriers), mortars per battalion and brigade per TM 30-410 tables
personnel_and_equipment.mitigation: War Office establishment tables (WO 24 series at National Archives), divisional war diaries with detailed strength returns (WO 169 series), or unit histories with appendices

notes: Q4 1942: Division at EL ALAMEIN (Egypt), Western Desert - XIII Corps southern sector alongside 7th Armoured Division and 50th Infantry Division
Deployed to North Africa: 29 May 1942 (departed UK), arrived Cairo 24 July 1942 via Cape of Good Hope
First action: Operation Braganza (29-30 Sep 1942) night raid by 131st Brigade

Battle of Alam el Halfa (31 Aug - 7 Sep 1942): Two brigades deployed along Alam el Halfa Ridge in prepared defensive positions with anti-tank guns and artillery, inflicted heavy losses on 15th and 21st Panzer Divisions. 132nd Brigade temporarily attached to 2nd NZ Division, suffered 697 casualties 3-4 Sep.
Second Battle of El Alamein (23 Oct - 11 Nov 1942): XIII Corps southern sector, defensive battle supporting armor operations
Commander: Major-General Ivor Hughes (from 15 March 1942, succeeded Brian Horrocks who went to command XIII Corps)
Brigade composition: 131st (Queen's/Surrey), 132nd (Kent & Surrey), 133rd (Royal Sussex) - all Home Counties Territorial battalions
Territorial Army division from Home Counties (Sussex, Kent, Surrey) - strong regional identity
Fresh division - only 4-5 months in theater before Alam el Halfa but well-trained and equipped
Division disbanded 31 January 1943 in North Africa - last engagement was El Alamein
